metadata.title: Top 14 Youtube Channels to Learn Python | by Claire D. Costa | Towards Data Science
metadata.h1: Top 14 Youtube Channels to Learn Python
metadata.description: Today, Python is being used by a wide majority of domains, such as application development, Data Science, Machine Learning, Artificial Intelligence, and much much more. Python’s increasing…

outgoing_paragraph_urls.anchor_text: the top YouTube channels for Data Science
Automate the Boring Stuff with Python

all_paragraphs: The joy of coding Python should be in seeing short, concise, readable classes that express a lot of action in a small amount of clear code — not in reams of trivial code that bores the reader to death.

Today, Python is being used by a wide majority of domains, such as application development, Data Science, Machine Learning, Artificial Intelligence, and much much more. Python’s increasing application in the real-world also helps ensure better career opportunities with some of the modern top-paying job roles. Python’s versatility is among the top reasons for its popularity. This popularity puts Python in a reasonably advantageous position in the software industry.

Now, we are witnessing a sharp rise in the wave of new developers picking Python as their first programming language, as well as more experienced developers looking to add Python to their list. There are dozens of sources where you can get a solid understanding of the long list of topics in Python, such as books, online courses, tutorials, websites, and podcasts.

YouTube has long been a capable platform that deserves to be on the list of reliable learning platforms for Python as millions of people actively use it for learning the programming language. You’ll find hundreds of Python-related channels on YouTube, but for this article, we gathered 13 popular and praise-worthy YouTube channels for you.
Before we start with our list, if you’re learning Python to get into Data Science, we recently did a write-up on the top YouTube channels for Data Science, and we highly recommend you give it a read.
According to Stackoverflow, Python is the most preferred language which means that the majority of developers use python.
Check Out Some Interesting Python Articles —

If you have made up your mind and want to learn Python, then you have a vast collection of resources to follow. Talking about Youtube channels in specific, you can find plenty of channels with a simple YouTube search. If you’ve already done that and were straight out baffled by the results, don’t worry, we’re here to simplify your search for the best YouTube channels for learning Python so that you can focus on the learning part. Our top picks are listed below:

freeCodeCamp.org is a well-known YouTube channel that is highly popular among programmers. Quincy Larson started this channel back in 2014 with the aim of making programming easier and accessible for anyone without ever paying a fee.

As of now, freeCodeCamp stands as one of the best resources for learning not just Python but a host of other programming languages. Apart from offering Python tutorials for absolute beginners, freeCodeCamp also offers Python-related video tutorials for handling tasks belonging to Deep Learning and Data Analysis domains.

freeCodeCamp’s website is home to a vast collection of valuable online tutorials and practice resources for a broad range of programming languages and domains, such as JavaScript, Python, HTML, CSS, Machine Learning, Data Analysis, and more. They also offer certification programs for a number of domains, including the ones mentioned above, which you might be interested in later on.
Mosh Hamedani’s channel has been up since 2014, and since then, it has garnered a lot of popularity, which is visible from his subscriber count.

Mosh’s clear and concise way of presenting topics to his viewers and doing so with only the best programming practices is the key highlight of the channel. A majority of his tutorial videos usually run on the longer side averaging anywhere from 40 minutes to a lengthy 6 hours.

Python beginners may find Mosh’s 6-hour long all-in-one Python for Beginners tutorial video intimidating but rest assured, his videos are wonderfully structured with plenty of timestamps, making navigation painless.

Mosh also offers online courses for other programming languages, such as Node.js, Java, C#, SQL, TypeScript, Angular, and much more on his website. If you like his teaching style and want to learn another programming language, we strongly recommend you check out his other courses.

The YouTube channel CS Dojo is the brainchild of YK Sugishita, who was a former Microsoft intern, an ex-Googler, and now a YouTuber. Upon visiting his channel, you’ll find a playlist titled “Python Tutorials for Absolute Beginners” where he has made getting started with Python programming as easy as possible.
YK follows a code-along approach in his videos, where his viewers can practice writing code side-by-side with him and even work on practice exercises.

It’s also his style of making topics crystal clear to his viewers, which makes the videos on his channel extremely easy to follow through. It is one of the core reasons for his channel’s growing popularity. For anyone wondering, rest assured, YK also provides an in-depth explanation about the solutions to his programming exercises.
His channel also goes over other useful topics, such as Data Structures and Algorithms, vital programming tips, and answers to commonly asked questions during coding interviews.

One of the best channels on our list, Harrison Kinsley created the channel sentdex in 2012, and it mainly covers topics related to Python. In Harrison’s videos, you’ll notice that he takes more of a practical approach to the topics rather than going with the boring theoretical approach. Although his channel is actually beginner friendly, I recommend doing a tiny bit of homework on getting an overall rough understanding of the topic before jumping on to the video. This way, you’ll be better able to understand the topic at hand.

His Python videos are suitable for new developers as well as intermediate ones. Apart from covering the various topics included in Python, Harrison has also covered a handful of other technologies, such as Machine Learning, Data Analysis, Robotics, Raspberry Pi, and more.
Harrison also has a website, which I suggest you check out, where he goes a bit deeper about each of his videos with an explanation and accompanying code examples.
Corey Schafer started his YouTube channel back in 2006, where he covers a range of programming languages and libraries, but the focus is primarily on Python.

Corey’s channel is jam-packed with convenient tutorials and walkthroughs for programmers of all skill levels. Beginners starting with Python will find everything from instructions on setting up the development environment to tutorials about the various introductory concepts in Python.

The best thing about the videos on Corey’s channel is once you get a solid understanding of the foundational concepts in Python, you’ll find plenty of tutorials on his channel where you can put your knowledge to the test.

Other programming languages and frameworks for which you’ll find tutorials on his channel include JavaScript, SQL, and Django. You’ll also find tutorials for some useful Data Science-centric Python libraries, such as Pandas for number crunching and Matplotlib for visualizations, explanation about frequently used programming terms, and some career advice.

If you’re looking for channels that make learning as fun and interesting as possible, then this might just be the right channel for you. Navin Reddy created the channel Telusko in 2014, where he covers the entirety of topics included in Python, playfully and clearly.
I recommend this channel for those taking baby steps in the world of Python programming, and even those who are new to programming, in general, should be able to benefit from this channel.

Look a little deeper and you’ll notice that Navin not only offers exhaustive video playlists covering Python but other programming languages and frameworks as well. The long list of programming languages includes Kotlin, Django, JavaScript, Hibernate, Blockchain, Java, Spring Framework 5, Angular 6, plus a lot more useful tips for programmers.
Real Python is also among one of the most reputed learning resource providers for people interested in learning Python.

Created by Dan Bader in 2013, you can think of Real Python as your one-stop-shop for learning topics that go beyond the introductory stuff. I’d say that the best audience for Real Python would be those people who have achieved a firm grasp of Python’s foundational topics and are looking for their next milestone.

Their YouTube channel covers everything from beginner-friendly tutorials, weekly podcasts, and coverage of Python events. You’ll also find crucial tips on a multitude of topics, such as how to write clear and better Python code, how to market yourself, steps on building a better career, useful programming tips, and much more.
Their podcast series consistently covers the latest happening from the world of Python with discussions with the best Python developers around the world.

Rafeh Qazi’s YouTube channel Clever Programmer sprung into action in 2016 and has been growing popular by the day. Rafeh frequently posts videos and streams live coding projects on his channel covering a plethora of topics and programming languages, but his channel mainly revolves around Python.
Not just Python, Rafeh has also posted tutorial videos about working with Django on his channel, providing the necessary learning materials to step into creating your first web application.
He has also uploaded videos that can help you answer several of the burning questions you might have as a beginner about why you should learn programming and what it can do for you.

One crucial aspect that sets Clever Programmer apart from other Python-related YouTube channels on our list is the focus on improving soft skills, which often gets lost in the process of acquiring the technical skills. Just a note, you might find the abundance of promotional content on his channel distracting.
Founded by Kimberly Hatch Harrison and Michael Harrison in 2011, Socratica is primarily a multidisciplinary YouTube channel where the majority of videos are on science and mathematics.

Socratica is home to a host of high-quality videos on a wide array of topics spread across multiple domains, such as science lessons, art lessons including Shakespear’s Sonnets, math videos covering algebra, calculus, geometry, and much more.

One of their many video playlists covers topics included in Python. The playlist is 33 videos long and provides a beginner-friendly approach to learning Python with the necessary introductory concepts and then moving on to a couple of more advanced topics.

Apart from the people interested in learning Python, I would also like to recommend this channel to students as it offers crucial tips for picking the right career path. If you’re interested to know more about Socratica, you should check out their website for more information.
thenewboston is undoubtedly one of the biggest and most-popular Python-oriented YouTube channels on our list, thanks to their enormous video count and an equally impressive subscriber count.

Getting back to the topic, the thenewboston YouTube channel was started by Bucky Roberts in 2008, and now it is home to an ever-growing collection of helpful tutorials and guides for learners for a long list of programming languages.

For beginners interested in learning Python, the playlist titled “Python 3.4 Programming Tutorials” is what we would like to recommend them to go through first. The playlist contains the right introductory topics for beginners and is pretty straightforward.

Later on, they can move on to building real-world projects like the web crawler and website scanners mentioned on the channel. Apart from covering tutorials for Python, some of the many programming languages covered in this channel include PHP, Angular, React, Node.js, and Django.
Albert Sweigart, who also goes by the name Al Sweigart, runs a YouTube channel where he teaches programming to both adults and kids.

Being created in 2007, Al’s YouTube channel still is one of the most preferred Python teaching channels for a lot of new and master developers. A large portion of his channel is centered around covering topics related to Python, while the rest of it is focussed on Scratch, a programming language targeted towards kids.

One of his playlists titled “Automate the Boring Stuff with Python” offers a deeper dive into much of the commonly used introductory topics, such as setting up Python, flow control, functions, lists, and more. The playlist takes inspiration from his book with the same name.

Apart from the similar introductory stuff, his book also covers a host of intermediate-level topics, such as pattern matching, input validation, reading/writing files, and a range of other widely used topics.
Like most other YouTube channels on our list, Chris’ YouTube channel is also a blend of tutorial videos from a bunch of programming languages and not just Python.

With his first upload dating back to 2013, his YouTube channel mostly revolves around tutorials covering Python, but you’ll also find other programming languages and frameworks such as React, Node.js, Django, ASP.NET Core, and JavaScript ES6.

We recommend new developers to start with the playlist titled “Python Beginner Tutorial” which covers everything from the basics to the more advanced topics, although there are several other Python playlists, like Python for Beginners 2019 and Learn Python 3.5.

Once you’re through with the mentioned playlist, you can either test this newfound knowledge by trying out several projects available online or proceed with completing the Learn Python 3.5 playlist. Either way, you now should be ready to move on to Python frameworks.

Created by Christian Thompson, a high school teacher in 2011, the channel TokyoEdtech has been providing beginners some of the easiest and comprehensive tutorials on getting into the world of programming.

The primary programming language of choice Christian uses on his channel is Python as he believes it offers the right mix of real-world applications with an extremely easy entry point but there’s a bit of Java as well. His channel mostly focuses on getting beginners started with developing some simple Python applications after completing the introductory stuff first.

Once they feel comfortable, the channel offers advanced tutorials on creating simple 2D games using Python with its popular game development libraries. Separated by different skill levels, such as beginners, intermediate, and advanced, TokyoEdtech offers learners plenty of options to pick their next project to get better at Python application development.

Ahmad’s python lectures vary from a module-specific approach (such as numpy, sympy, etc.), so that novice or advanced python users could get a vibe of what the diverse features of a given module is, to an application-based approach, demonstrating all the wonderful features of python has to offer in our daily life.

From an application perspective, and to fully leverage python, Ahmad shows different cool stuff you can do with python. These applications include, but are not limited to, stock market analysis, mathematical Convex Optimization, operational research, algorithmic trading, network socket programming, conversational AI, and more to come.
If you’re a college student or just someone who’s curious to get started with Python, this tutorial could be the right choice for you in an efficient way

Python’s rise to the top of the best programming languages is inevitable. The idea behind this write-up is to highlight some popular and praise-worthy YouTube channels that are doing an excellent job at teaching Python.
What are your thoughts on this list? Did your favorite channel make it to the list? We’re eager to hear from you!
Oh, and by the way, if podcasts are your thing, you should definitely check out our list of top podcasts for learning Python, which we also covered a few articles back.
Note: To eliminate problems of different kinds, I want to alert you to the fact this article represent just my personal opinion I want to share, and you possess every right to disagree with it.
If you have more suggestions, I’d love to hear about them.
I hope you’ve found this article useful! Below are some interesting readings hope you like them too-

Claire D. is a Content Crafter and Marketer at Digitalogy — a tech sourcing and custom matchmaking marketplace that connects people with pre-screened & top-notch developers and designers based on their specific needs across the globe. Connect with me on Medium, Linkedin, & Twitter.
